i try to mount it via:
mount /dev/sda
2008-05-14T09:10:00.000Z	hiro1000		but it gives me mount: can't find /dev/sda in /etc/fstab or /etc/mtab
you would try to mount a partition of device sda like sda1 for instance. But likely that drive is already mounted as your root filesystem. To see whats mounted under what directories do: mount

Firstly, just:  mount/dev/sda1 will do nothing. You need to tell it a place to make it available (a directory)   so something like: mount /dev/sda1 /mnt/sda1     (if you have made the directory of sda1 inside the directory of /mnt)
Also if the drive is not native linux filesystem you will need to tell mount command what to try like ntfsor such with -t filesystemnamehere
Use sudo in front of mount command then and put your usual pasword when asked
how do i specify a filesystem
eg:   sudo mount -t somefilesystemname /dev/sda1 /mnt/sda1                for instance and put for "somefilesystemname" something like ntfs or what it should be
In that example the directory sda1 must exist as I said earlier elsewhere
What is the result of the command:   sudo fdisk -l /dev/sda1
Apologies, should be:   sudo fdisk -l /dev/sda               only and not sda1
